image.title: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication

item.title: Communicating About COVID-19: Practices for Today, Planning for Tomorrow
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 50, Issue 3, Page 211-223, July 2020.
In times of public health crises, effective information on how to perform daily activities can be central to the stability of local communities. Technical communicators can make important contributions to these situations by developing materials that meet local informational needs. This entry reviews strategies technical communicators can use to address public health challenges on the local level both today and in the future.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 50, Issue 3, Page 211-223, July 2020.

item.dc:title: Communicating About COVID-19: Practices for Today, Planning for Tomorrow
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Kirk St.Amant
item.prism:publicationName: Communicating About COVID-19: Practices for Today, Planning for Tomorrow

item.title: High-Impact Civic Engagement: Outcomes of Community-Based Research in Technical Writing Courses
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 50, Issue 3, Page 224-251, July 2020.
This article reports on the first stage of a mixed-methods community-based research project involving residents of a socioeconomically challenged neighborhood in Baltimore City, Richnor Springs, and service-learning students in technical and professional communication courses at Loyola University Maryland (Loyola). To measure outcomes, we analyzed student surveys from 80 respondents and critical reflections from two students. We also analyzed interviews from two students and two community members. Findings indicate that there were no statistical mean differences in the educational experiences between service-learning and nonservice-learning students; however, there were significant mean differences in transformational experiences. Findings also indicate that community members responded positively and that stakeholders valued the personal relationships that developed.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 50, Issue 3, Page 224-251, July 2020.
This article reports on the first stage of a mixed-methods community-based research project involving residents of a socioeconomically challenged neighborhood in Baltimore City, Richnor Springs, and service-learning students in technical and professional communication courses at Loyola University Maryland (Loyola). To measure outcomes, we analyzed student surveys from 80 respondents and critical reflections from two students. We also analyzed interviews from two students and two community members. Findings indicate that there were no statistical mean differences in the educational experiences between service-learning and nonservice-learning students; however, there were significant mean differences in transformational experiences. Findings also indicate that community members responded positively and that stakeholders valued the personal relationships that developed.
item.dc:title: High-Impact Civic Engagement: Outcomes of Community-Based Research in Technical Writing Courses
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Allen Brizee
Paola Pascual-Ferrá
Giuliana Caranante
item.prism:publicationName: High-Impact Civic Engagement: Outcomes of Community-Based Research in Technical Writing Courses

item.title: Writing, in English, for Publication in Science and Technology, and Policy: The Example of Nuclear Security
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 50, Issue 3, Page 252-288, July 2020.
This article considers best practices for writing articles in science, technology, and policy, focusing on writing for international scholarly journals in nuclear security. Its two main audiences are technical communication educators/researchers and internationals wishing to publish their work in English-medium scholarly journals. I discuss publishing scenarios and challenges facing such authors and offer guidelines for producing clear, effective, publishable articles, in English, for international discourse. My approach is based on traditional rhetorical principles, plain language studies, research pursued at nuclear security conferences, feedback from internationals at writing workshops, and my experience as editor of the International Journal of Nuclear Security.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 50, Issue 3, Page 252-288, July 2020.
This article considers best practices for writing articles in science, technology, and policy, focusing on writing for international scholarly journals in nuclear security. item.dc:title: Writing, in English, for Publication in Science and Technology, and Policy: The Example of Nuclear Security
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Russel Hirst
item.prism:publicationName: Writing, in English, for Publication in Science and Technology, and Policy: The Example of Nuclear Security

item.title: Beginning With Ganesha: The Founding and Early History of the Society for Technical Communication in India
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 50, Issue 3, Page 289-307, July 2020.
Scholars have given much weight to the question of professional legitimacy in the field of TPC, but much of that focus has been given to practitioners in Euro-Western contexts. However, practitioners in India have also worked to strengthen their own legitimacy in a variety of ways, including by harnessing existing structural mechanisms. This article addresses the founding of the Society for Technical Communication India chapter in 1999 and its subsequent organizational impact as a mechanism toward improving the legitimacy of the field in India. It covers a historical analysis of the founding years of the Society for Technical Communication India chapter and discusses ways that founding members and early participants worked to build their own legitimacy.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 50, Issue 3, Page 289-307, July 2020.
Scholars have given much weight to the question of professional legitimacy in the field of TPC, but much of that focus has been given to practitioners in Euro-Western contexts. However, practitioners in India have also worked to strengthen their own legitimacy in a variety of ways, including by harnessing existing structural mechanisms. This article addresses the founding of the Society for Technical Communication India chapter in 1999 and its subsequent organizational impact as a mechanism toward improving the legitimacy of the field in India. It covers a historical analysis of the founding years of the Society for Technical Communication India chapter and discusses ways that founding members and early participants worked to build their own legitimacy.
item.dc:title: Beginning With Ganesha: The Founding and Early History of the Society for Technical Communication in India
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Breeanne Matheson
item.prism:publicationName: Beginning With Ganesha: The Founding and Early History of the Society for Technical Communication in India

item.title: A Day in the Life: Personas of Professional Communicators at Work
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 50, Issue 3, Page 308-335, July 2020.
This article uses personas to illustrate the range of technical communication knowledge work developed through its practitioners—to articulate the functions, characteristics, traits, skills, and workplace styles of positions someone in the field might pursue. Recent research has provided valuable data about the expanding and evolving skill sets of the technical/professional communicator. We build on that by triangulating the data from an analysis of job postings, a survey of technical communicators, and interviews and embedded observations of practitioners to develop personas of technical/professional communicators on the job. The personas can help students, programs, and practitioners understand and navigate the many types of roles that are available in the field.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 50, Issue 3, Page 308-335, July 2020.
This article uses personas to illustrate the range of technical communication knowledge work developed through its practitioners—to articulate the functions, characteristics, traits, skills, and workplace styles of positions someone in the field might pursue. Recent research has provided valuable data about the expanding and evolving skill sets of the technical/professional communicator. We build on that by triangulating the data from an analysis of job postings, a survey of technical communicators, and interviews and embedded observations of practitioners to develop personas of technical/professional communicators on the job. The personas can help students, programs, and practitioners understand and navigate the many types of roles that are available in the field.
item.dc:title: A Day in the Life: Personas of Professional Communicators at Work
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Eva Brumberger
Claire Lauer
item.prism:publicationName: A Day in the Life: Personas of Professional Communicators at Work

item.title: Student Social Media Self-Evaluation: Addressing the Posting Paradox in the Age of Cybervetting
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
Cybervetting, or the review of job applicants’ social media accounts, is a common practice. This study investigates the use of a typology to increase students’ self-awareness by asking them to assess their social media presence. The majority of Facebook users concluded they post content that is appropriate for potential employers, while most Twitter users concluded they post questionable content. Yet most Facebook users restricted access to their accounts, while most Twitter users left them public. When subsequently asked about the prospect of changing posting behavior, students with questionable content were more open to change, supporting the potential viability of the typology.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.

item.dc:title: Student Social Media Self-Evaluation: Addressing the Posting Paradox in the Age of Cybervetting
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: James Melton
Robert Miller
Paul Dunn
item.prism:publicationName: Student Social Media Self-Evaluation: Addressing the Posting Paradox in the Age of Cybervetting
